Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Thin Silicon Solar Cells for Aerospace Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to enable the emerging and rapidly growing markets of solar powered aerospace devices. The solar array is often the most expensive component of satellites, drones and airships and reducing their cost 10 times while also reducing the weight 5 times and making solar cells flexible can disrupt one of the main barriers for the growing private aerospace economy. The major target market for thin silicon solar cells is the constellations of thousands of new satellites at the lower earth orbit for providing Global Satellite Internet and IoT device communications. Global Internet can make a broader impact on the human life in three areas: (1) enable worldwide communications, (2) stimulate economic growth in developing countries by providing Internet connection, (3) establish more sustainable societies by providing access to education, ensuring the freedom of speech and providing the instruments for electronic democracy. Another major target market is drones for surveillance and remote monitoring and airships for cargo transportation. In the future, thin silicon solar cells can become the ultimate source of energy for solar powered space transportation, asteroid mining and colonization of Mars and the Moon.

The proposed project will develop two innovations which can enable mass production of thin Si solar cells for aerospace applications. There are two main roadblocks for using thin Si solar cells commercially. First, is that efficiency of thin silicon cells drops by 4-6%. Second, is that 10-micron-thick Si wafers cannot be manufactured using standard Si solar cell fabrication methods. Regher Solar has developed two innovations to enable mass production of thin Si cells with >20% efficiency. The first innovation is processing of 10-micron-thick on thicker Si wafers to use them for handling. The second innovation is using silicon heterojunction technology with copper metallization, which achieves the highest efficiency when the cell is only 10 microns thick. The overall goal of this SBIR proposal is to develop lower cost, high efficiency, flexible, reliable and manufacturable solar cells based on thin Si technology for the rapidly growing market of solar powered aerospace devices. The specific goals of this Phase I project are: (1) finalize a process flow, (2) achieve >22% AM0 efficiency, >2000 W/kg specific power, >200 W/m2 power density on a 10-micron-thick wafer; (3) conduct a comprehensive reliability testing of thin Si solar cells; (4) demonstrate flexible blankets.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this Phase I project Regher Solar has developed a novel type of a photovoltaic silicon solar cell that is optimized for being used in space.

Almost all existing satellites are powered by sunlight converted into electricity using photovoltaic solar arrays, so each satellite is equipped with a solar array. A new class of space projects being presently developed implies using tens of thousands of mid-size satellites in the low Earth orbit to provide global broadband satellite internet connectivity. All these new satellites will need hundreds of times more solar panels than the existing space solar industry can manufacture and at significantly lower cost. The problem is that scaling of manufacturing using the presently used technology is not possible because of multiple materials, equipment, and trained workforce bottlenecks.

To solve this problem Regher Solar proposed to use terrestrial silicon solar cell technology that can already meet the demand from the megaconstellation projects both in terms of manufacturing capacity and cost.

However, terrestrial silicon solar cells are subject to relative fast degradation in space radiation. To solve this issue, Regher Solar proposed to reduce the thickness of terrestrial silicon solar cells from 160 microns to 20 microns and use defect engineering to mitigate radiation induced damage. However, making a silicon solar cell thin represents a separate challenge because the manufacturing technology (set of tools and a process flow) are not compatible with processing of 20-micron-thick silicon wafers. In addition, previous efforts to make silcon solar cells that thin cuased the efficiency to drop below the acceptable level due to the insufficient surface passivation.

The main outcome of this project was a demonstration that 20-micron-thick Si solar cells can be processed in a pilot production environment and achieve a competitive efficiency.

Another challenge with 20-micron-thick Si solar cells is the absence of technology to package them into panels. A more general problem with packaging of space solar cells was using welded metal joints and thin, space-tolerant pieces of glass applied to each individual solar cell by hand. Both steps increased manufacturing cost and make automated mass production impossible.

The second outcome of this Phase I project was a conceptualization of the design and a process flow to fabricate flexible solar blankets that can enable packaging of 20-micron-thick Si solar cells and at the same time allow automated mass production. Qualification, pilot production and industry acceptance of flexible silicon blankets for satellites formed the basis of Phase II application.
